data.title: Research: Ancient history, contemporary belonging
data.meta_description: Young people from refugee backgrounds will create new biographies of Manchester museum’s ancient historical objects.
data.text:
Research summary

Begins September 2021

The project involves young people from refugee backgrounds writing new descriptions of historical objects taken from their ancestral homelands.

Up to 20 ‘citizen scientists’ aged 16-24 are being recruited to work with researchers and community artists on new descriptions for artefacts held by Manchester Museum.

They will conduct archival research and draw on their own life experiences for a new exhibition, which aims to increase public understanding of the forced migration of both people and objects. The new biographies will also be added to the museum’s online archives.

Manchester Museum’s collection includes artefacts from Africa (primarily Egypt and northern Sudan), the eastern Mediterranean (Syria, Palestine), and western Asia (Iran, Iraq).

They were acquired during the late 19th and early 20th centuries, at a time when British colonial influence enabled the removal of vast quantities of archaeological material. These regions overlap significantly with the countries of origin of many of the UK’s contemporary forced migrants.
